The Cabinet took note of a Memorandum bythe Secretary of State for the Colonies (CP.-188(32)) circulating telegrams from the -Governor of malta, from which it was clear that the Bishops'Pastoral of 1930 had been superseded. The Cabinet took note of a Memorandum bythe Minister of Labour (C.P.-187 (32)) on thesubject of the prospective employment situation,intimating that in the absence of a substantialrecovery in the trade of the world we were likelyto be faced with a volume of unemployment next winter greater than anything experienced previously .A short discussion took place on the above memorandum., in the course of which the Ministerof Labour gave some figures to show that theposition was, perhaps, not quite so bad as indicatedtherein, owing to the effect of the Whitsuntideholiday. Some unemployment, he added, was due tothe recent floods. He feared, however, that theunemployment estimates on which the Budget had been based could not possibly be realised.The Chancellor of the Exchequer gave somefigures as to the probable effect on the budget of the estimated increase in the unemployment figures, but asked that his colleagues, in any public statements, should not say anything toencourage a spirit of pessimism. parliamentary procedure.(previous reference:Cabinet 31(33)% Con-clusion 2 .)6.. After a short discussion, the Cabinet agreedThat on the conclusion of the present session, Parliament should be askedto adjourn and should not be prorogued,and that the decision should be upheldon the ground, that legislation mightbe required at short notice as theresult of one or other of the Confer-ences now in being or about to takeplace. 7. The President of the Board of Trade made ashort verbal report to the Cabinet on the satisfactoryconeIns ion of the Coal negotiations. He paid a tribute to Mr Evan Williams and to Mr Ebby Edwardsfor their assistance from the point of view of theOwners and the Miners respectively. He added thatthe point which was most exercising the minds ofthe miners was that at the end of the twelve months the National Industrial Board should exercise somefunctions. That raised the question of negotiations between the Owners and the Miners. Up to the presenttime the Owners had boycotted the Board, and theOwners who were members of the Board were merenominees of the Government and in no way repre-sentative. Pie hoped, however, that he mightsucceed in persuading the Owners to take some active part in the Board, without interfering in rates ofwages .The Prime Minister said that this was a goodpiece of business accomplished. rpjTE LAUSANNE 8. APPENDIXCopy No.cabinet.Civil Service Remuneration.Memorandum circulated "by direction of the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer.The following arrangements are subject at all stages of their operation to the country's ability to pay;that is to say, the maintenance thereunder of any givenstandard of Civil Service remuneration cannot be absoulutely guaranteed but is subject to the overriding consideration of the national financial position ;(1) The Government adhere to the decision toabandon the system under which the Civil Service wageslevel varies automatically with variations in the costof living figure and to introduce instead the principleof consolidated remuneration which will be subject to consideration in the light of any substantial changesupwards or downwards in the level of remunerationoutside the Civil Service.(2) Having regard, however, to the views of theStaff Side that the present is not an opportune time forconsolidation, consolidation will be deferred till1st April, 1934. In the meantime there will be aperiod of stabilisation at present rates based on a cost-of-living figure of 50, subject to the followingarrangement :SECRET. 197 (32)(THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'3 GOVERNMENT.)TO B E KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special c are may be taken to ensure the secrecy of this document. (3) No review of the general level of wages as sostabilised will fall to he made unless for six consecutivemonths during the period of stabilisation the cost ofliving figure is either below 40 or above 60;(4) If either of these events happens during the"Stabilised" period, a review of the general level ofCivil Service remuneration will be undertaken in thelight of all the relevant considerations, from whichthe position of the cost-of-living figure will not be excluded.Treasury Chambers, S.W. 1.7th June 1932.
